definition:
An action potential occurs when the membrane potential of a specific cell
rapidly rises and falls. This depolarization then causes adjacent locations to similarly depolarize. Action
potentials occur in several types of animal cells, called excitable cells, which include neurons, muscle cells,
and in some plant cells. Certain endocrine cells such as pancreatic beta cells, and certain cells of the anterior
&%PituitaryGland are also excitable cells. In neurons, action potentials play a central role in cell–cell
communication by providing for—or with regard to saltatory conduction, assisting—the propagation of signals along
the neuron's axon toward synaptic boutons situated at the ends of an axon; these signals can then connect with
other neurons at synapses, or to motor cells or glands.[from Wikipedia]
